body.p: Some fonts do not have a bold or italic variant, and Chemistry falls back automatically to the regular font. In this topic you will learn how to instruct Chemistry to synthesize font variants. Do not use this technique if you have all the font components.

section.title: Using a simulated styles font from a true type font collection (ttc)

note.p: There is a limitation in Chemistry:

The @font-face rules in your CSS work as expected when they are pointing to a .ttf file. If you intend to use a .ttc collection, the value of the font-family property should exactly match one of the font names from the collection (a collection contains multiple fonts).

section.p: In the following example we will use the Microsoft JhengHei font (the msjh.ttc). Many of the Chinese fonts provide regular, light, bold, but no italic or bold-italic variants. In this case you may want Chemistry to generate the missing variants for you.
To use the regular variant, use a simple@font-face definition, making sure the font-family is found in the collection:
For the missing style combinations, we will use the -oxy-simulate-style: yes CSS extension property.
